entry.title: SAP CIS ‚Üî SAP Ariba User Provisioning Issue (SCIM Schema mismatch)
entry.content:
Hello Community,

we are currently implementing user provisioning between SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) and SAP Ariba and followed the official SAP guide:
üëâ SAP Ariba User Provisioning using SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)

In this guide, it is recommended to create the following custom schema:

urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:vendor:ariba:2.0:User

We created this schema and successfully populated the attributes inside SAP CIS.
However, during provisioning from CIS to SAP Ariba, we noticed that the attributes are completely ignored and not recognized in Ariba.

The reason is a schema mismatch:

  • Schema delivered by CIS (wrong):

     
    urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap.ariba:2.0:User

  • Schema expected by Ariba SCIM API (correct):

     
    urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:ariba:2.0:User

    The difference is small (sap.ariba vs. sap:ariba), but it prevents Ariba from accepting the attributes.
    As a result, although CIS contains the attributes, they never arrive in Ariba.

    Workaround we applied

    We manually built the correct Ariba schema in CIS, adjusted the user attributes, and extended the transformations accordingly. With this workaround, provisioning into Ariba now works as expected.

    Questions to the community

    1. Is this workaround acceptable as a long-term solution, or could it cause issues with future updates?

      We would greatly appreciate any insights or experiences with similar setups üôè

      Best regards,
      Said

entry.title: Implementing OIDC Authentication for SuccessFactors API Integration
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

Requirement Overview:
We are working on integrating a front-end application with SuccessFactors. In this scenario, users log in through the front-end application and request their information from SuccessFactors. To enable this, we need to expose the SuccessFactors OData APIs to this application.

SuccessFactors OData APIs support OAuth 2.0 with SAML Assertion. The typical process is:

  1. Request a SAML assertion.

  2. Use the SAML assertion to obtain an access token.

  3. Use the access token to query the APIs.

Currently, for the SAML assertion step, we are using the /oauth/idp API to generate SAML assertions for our exposed APIs. This setup is working, but as per the official documentation (link), this method is considered insecure and has been deprecated, which may affect the APIs we expose to external systems going forward.

Proposed Solution:
We are planning to implement OIDC-based authentication for the APIs exposed from SuccessFactors to external systems.

  • We followed the official guide to configure the Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning services (link) and attempted testing using Postman.

  • During testing (Step 10), we were asked to select the ‚ÄúSAP SuccessFactors‚Äù application, but the option only works when ‚ÄúAdministration Console‚Äù is selected.

Further testing, as per this guide, yielded the following:

  • We successfully called the /oauth2/token API and obtained an ID token from the Identity Authentication service.

  • We made a second API call to obtain an API access token using the ID token from the previous step.

  • However, using this access token, we are unable to access APIs in the SAP SuccessFactors HCM suite. Getting the 401 authentication error while querying SuccessFactors OData APIs:

    Error Response:
    **********************
    {
    "error": {
    "code": "AuthenticationFailed",
    "message": "Authentication service failed to return token.",
    "details": "Failed to authenticated OIDC token"
    }
    }
    ************************

Key Requirements:

  • The official documentation suggests using grant_type=password, which we want to avoid for security reasons.

  • We intend to use grant_type=authorization_code so that users can log in via SSO through the front-end application, and their session can be used to access the APIs.

  • We would appreciate guidance on setting this up, specifically:

    1. How to configure the authentication flow for users logging in through the front-end application.

    2. How to configure it when an application (rather than users) needs to consume SuccessFactors APIs.

We request your help in setting this up correctly and securely. Leads to documentation/blog posts or any sort of help will be highly appreciated. 

@CarlosRoggan @DeepakGDeshpande 

Regards,
Pavan

entry.title: Development of client-facing app in SAP BTP - Authentication and User management
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am working on the development of an SAPUI5 application in SAP BTP using SAP Business Application Studio. The idea is that this application will be deployed using SAP Build Workzone, Standard edition. This application acts like a simple portal where a small subset of the company's customers (~5 customers, which themselves are also companies) will need to access from outsite the organization where the app will be hosted. Based on the logged in user, the portal will display data regarding to the business partner that user represents (this I believe a mapping between the user and the BP code in SAP is enough). The Odata service itself is not that complex (in the sense that will retrieve sales data for the customer, so it's pretty much an Odata service that will retrieve data from sales tables like VBAK, VBAP, etc. For context, I'm working with a on-premise ECC EHP7 backend. An high level diagram of the development is as below:

 

‚ÄÉ

As I am fairly new to BTP Identity solutions, I believe that the main point here is regarding the expositure of this app in SAP BTP for people outside the organization (third party access). One of the requirements is that the management of the credentials for these customers would be done entirely on my organization's side, for better control: we would not want anyone with access to the app to request an user account there.

There are a handful of possibilites, but i'd like to understand what would be the best approaches (or at least an combination of approaches). I thought of the following approaches:

1) try to manage the authentication with a developed user service - besides being less safe, I believe this is not possible due to the security layet BTP itself has, so you'd need to have a valid user to authenticate with BTP before accessing the portal.

2) Use SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS alone), with its Local User Store and without both Self Service registration and Social Identity Providers - Users would be created by administrators, and the password sent to them, in a similar fashion to what's done with service keys for Integration Suite scenarios. Similar to the scenario in https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/business-to-business-scenario?locale=en-US, considering a single user per customer (or even https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/business-to-consumer-scenario?locale=en-US without the possibility of the user creating an access to themselves

3) Use SAP Cloud Identity Services (not only IAS) to manage the integration with the corporate identity provider of the organization i'm working (Microsoft Entra ID). I believe this can be more complex as we'd shift the control of the user maintenance to the organization's Identity Provider, so some sort of federation/trust would be required between SAP Cloud Identity Services and Entra ID.

 
This looks like a common (or at least, not very uncommon) scenario, so I would appreciate guidances or suggestions on the best path for this auth.
 
Thanks in Advance,
Erick Grilo.

entry.title: IAM for SAP Joule
entry.content:
üîê IAM for SAP Joule: Building Secure, Scalable AI Experiences
As organizations embrace SAP Joule and SAP Business AI, Identity and Access Management (IAM) becomes the backbone of secure and seamless integration across business applications. Here‚Äôs what you need to know:

‚úÖ Why IAM Matters for Joule
SAP Joule is more than a conversational AI‚Äîit connects processes and data across multiple SAP applications. To achieve this, robust IAM architecture ensures:
Cross-domain access without compromising security.
Consistent user experience across integrated apps.
Compliance with enterprise cybersecurity standards.

üîë Core IAM Components
SAP Cloud Identity Services
Joule uses these services as its user store, enabling centralized identity management and role-based access.
OpenID Connect (OIDC)
The recommended protocol for secure integration between Joule and SAP Business AI.
Role Mapping & Session Management
Content is exposed based on role names, and user-to-role assignments occur dynamically during sessions.

üõ† Integration Flow
Initial Setup: Configure Joule with SAP Cloud Identity Services.
Common Data Model (CDM): Define which Joule functions map to specific roles.
Cross-Application IAM: Once the first app integrates with Joule, subsequent apps reuse the same IAM patterns.

üåê Navigation & Access
SAP Joule leverages SAP Build Work Zone for unified navigation across applications, ensuring smooth transitions for end users.

üí° Why This Matters
IAM for Joule isn‚Äôt just about authentication‚Äîit‚Äôs about enabling secure, intelligent collaboration across SAP‚Äôs ecosystem. As AI becomes central to enterprise workflows, IAM ensures trust, compliance, and scalability.

üëâ What‚Äôs your take? How do you see IAM evolving as AI-driven platforms like Joule become mainstream?
